facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 649 of 1964 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 30, 1963 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in W.P. No. 1061 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 649 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 30, 1963 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in W.P. No. 1061 of 1962. Arun B. Saharya and Sardar Bahadur, for the appellant.

facts.text: The appellant manufactures drugs in Hyderabad including chloral hydrate.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant manufactures drugs in Hyderabad and among the drugs manufactured by it is chloral hydrate. In September 1962, the State of Andhra Pradesh issued rules called the Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: In September 1962, the State of Andhra Pradesh issued rules called the Andhra Pradesh Telangana Area Chloral Hydrate Chloral Rules, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In September 1962, the State of Andhra Pradesh issued rules called the Andhra Pradesh  Telangana Area  Chloral Hydrate  Chloral  Rules, 1962 with respect to manufacture, possession, sale, import, export and transport of chloral hyd- rate  hereinafter referred to as the Rules .

facts.text: The Rules provide that manufacture of chloral hydrate shall take place only in accordance with conditions of a licence granted by the Excise Commissioner and only on payment of excise duty of Rs. 500/- per annum.

anchor.surface_text: We shall refer to the Rules in detail later but in brief they provide that the manufacture of chloral hydrate shall take place only in accordance with the companyditions of a licence granted by the Excise Commissioner and only on payment of excise duty of Rs. 5001- per annum.

facts.text: The Rules also provide for possession, import, export, sale and transport of chloral hydrate.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules also provide for possession, import, export, sale and transport of chloral hydrate. In companysequence of the issue of the Rules, the appellant was called upon to take out a licence and pay the necessary excise duty.

facts.text: In consequence of the issue of the Rules, the appellant was called upon to take out a licence and pay the necessary excise duty.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence of the issue of the Rules, the appellant was called upon to take out a licence and pay the necessary excise duty. The appellant refused to do so and in November 1962 filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging inter alia the validity of the Rules.

facts.text: The appellant refused to take out a licence and pay excise duty and in November 1962 filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging inter alia the validity of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant refused to do so and in November 1962 filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging inter alia the validity of the Rules. It may be mentioned that the Rules were issued under the Andhra Pradesh  Telangana Area  Intoxicating Drugs Act, No. IV of 1333 Fasli,

facts.text: The Rules were issued under the Andhra Pradesh Telangana Area Intoxicating Drugs Act, No. IV of 1333 Fasli (1333-F Act) as amended by the Hyderabad Opium and Intoxicating Drugs Amendment Act, No. XXII of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the Rules were issued under the Andhra Pradesh  Telangana Area  Intoxicating Drugs Act, No. IV of 1333 Fasli,  hereinafter referred to as the 1333-F Act  as amended by the Hyderabad Opium and Intoxicating Drugs  Amendment  Act, No. XXII of 1953.

facts.text: The main contention of the appellant in the High Court was that the 1333-F Act had been repealed in toto on the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act, No. 2 of 1930 by the Opium and Revenue Laws Extension of application Act, No. 33 of 1950, and of the Drugs Act, No. 23 of 1940 by the Part B States Laws Act, No. III of 1951.

facts.text: The petition was opposed on behalf of the State which contended that there was no repeal of the 1333-F Act by the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act 1930 and the Drugs Act, 1940, and consequently the amendment by Hyderabad Act No. 22 of 1953 was good, and the 1333-F Act as amended was in force in 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was opposed on behalf of the State, and it company- tended that there was numberrepeal of the 1333-F Act by the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act 1930 and the Drugs Act, 1940, and companysequently the amendment of the 1333-F Act by the Hyderabad Act No. 22 of 1953 was good, and the 1333-F Act as amended was in force in 1962 when the Rules were framed.

facts.text: The 1333-F Act was in force in Hyderabad State from 1924.

anchor.surface_text: The 1333-F Act was in force in Hyderabad State as it was before the Constitution from 1924. At that time the, State of Hyderabad was a sovereign State and had full power to deal with all subjects number companytained in Lists 1, II and III of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution

facts.text: Parliament applied the Dangerous Drugs Act No. 2 of 1930 to Part B State of Hyderabad by Central Act 33 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In 1950, Parliament applied the Opium Act  No. 13 of 1857 , the Opium Act  t of 1878  and the Dangerous Drugs Act  No. 2 of 1930  to the Part B State of Hyderabad by Central Act 33 of 1950.

facts.text: The court holds that the 1333-F Act was not completely repealed by introduction of Dangerous Drugs Act and Drugs Act.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 30, 1963 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in W.P. No. 1061 of 1962. Arun B. Saharya and Sardar Bahadur, for the appellant. Ram Reddy and T. V. R. Tatachari, for respondent No. No. 1.

The High Court repelled the contentions raised on behalf of the appellant and dismissed the writ petition. The appellant then applied for a certificate for leave to appeal to this Court, which was refused. It then obtained special leave from this Court and that is how the matter has come before us.

issues.text: whether the 1333-F Act survived the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act and the Drugs Act in the State of Hyderabad

anchor.surface_text: We now come to the first point raised on behalf of the appellant, namely, whether the 1333-F Act survived the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act and the Drugs Act in the State of Hyderabad. The 1333-F Act was in force in Hyderabad State as it was before the Constitution from 1924.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 649 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 30, 1963 of the Andhra Prad

holdings.text: The introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act in the Part B State of Hyderabad in 1950 did not result in complete effacement of the 1333-F Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act in the Part B State of Hyderabad in 1950 did number result in companyplete effacement of the, 1333-F Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dangerous Drugs Act concerns prohibition/control, not excise duties; s.39 preserves state laws with greater restrictions; substance can fall under multiple lists; no implied repeal of excise provisions.

holdings.text: The introduction of the Drugs Act of 1940 did not repeal the excise provisions of the 1333-F Act; the Act continued in existence for collection of duties of excise and could be amended by Hyderabad Act No. 22 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt therefore that the 1333-F Act continued in existence so far as it dealt with collection of duties of excise on substances covered by it and it could therefore be amended by Hyderabad Act No. 22 of 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Drugs Act concerns quality/standards, additional to other laws per s.2; no effect on state excise duties under List II item 51; no implied repeal.

holdings.text: Chloral hydrate is a narcotic or a narcotic drug within the meaning of entry 51 of List II of the Seventh Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no other conclusion on the evidence in the present case than that chloral hydrate is a narcotic or a narcotic drug within the meaning of entry 51 of List 11 of the Seventh Schedule. It also has intoxicating effect when mixed with liquor

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary definition as hypnotic/sedative producing sleep/stupor; appellant admission; state evidence of intoxicating effect with liquor; state affidavit context limited to 1955 Act definition.

holdings.text: Chloral hydrate is an intoxicating and narcotic substance within the amended 1333-F Act; the 1962 Rules are within the power conferred by the Act.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the second point raised in the present appeal, namely, that even if the 1333-F Act had not been completely repealed by the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act and the Drugs Act and could be properly amended by the Hyderabad Act of 1953, the Rules were not within the power conferred by the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notified under s.2(1)(iv); narcotic per List II 51; liable to excise duty Rs.500/annum and incidental controls (licence, possession etc.); overlaps with central drug laws permitted.

holdings.text: The appellant is not permitted to raise for the first time in Supreme Court the contention that chloral hydrate is a medicinal preparation under the Medicinal and Toilet Preparations Excise Duties Act, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The licence which has been produced shows that chloral hydrate is being manufactured under the Drugs Act and the rules framed thereunder. Further the judgment of the High Court shows that no argument was raised before it

holdings.reasoning_summary: No clear averment in writ petition; licence under Drugs Act 1940, not 1955 Act; no argument raised in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled the contentions raised on behalf of the appellant and dismissed the writ petition. The appellant then applied for a certificate for leave to appeal to this Court, which was refused.

outcome.relief_summary: Writ petition challenging validity of Chloral Hydrate Rules dismissed by High Court; Supreme Court rejects all contentions of appellant upholding validity of the Act and Rules
